ygData.subject: Re: Benchmarks for Artificial Embryogeny Systems
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Derek, I m not really aware of much, if any benchmarking work that has been done in the field other than some of the papers mentioned in the other post.  An

Hi Derek,

I'm not really aware of much, if any benchmarking work that has =
been
done in the field other than some of the papers mentioned in the other=

post.  An outsider might think our ultimate goal is to create a French
fla=
g!  I think it would be great to see such benchmarking of
artificial embryo=
geny, as things seem to be about the same as when Ken
wrote his paper: ever=
yone is just trying stuff with their own system,
without any regard to the =
other systems out there.

Ken and I did try to do something like (although =
not as indepth as his
paper suggests) with my 2007 HyperNEAT paper's result=
s.  I built a
program that let me look at the Hypercube patterns and we wer=
e able to
learn a lot about HyperNEAT by watching how the patterns changed =
over
evolution, and were able to isolate modules that contributed to things=

like symmetry.  We have a forthcoming journal publication about
HyperNEAT =
in general that talks a bit about this.

David

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com=
, "Derek James" <djames@...> wrote:
>
> Seeing Peter Krcah's stuff (http://=
ero.matfyz.cz/) at GECCO this year
> got me re-interested in artificial emb=
ryogeny. I went back and reread
> Ken's paper "A Taxonomy for Artificial Em=
bryogeny"
> (http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/pub-view.php?PubID=3D121), which is a =
very nice
> paper. I was specifically wondering about the suggestions at th=
e end
> of the paper, regarding benchmarks for AE systems, such as:
> 
> Ev=
olution of:
> 
> --Pure symmetry (e.g. bilateral symmetry)
> --Specific sha=
pes (e.g. rings, stars, and trees)
> --Specific connectivity patterns (e.g.=
 for neural networks)
> --Simple controllers (e.g. for double pole balancin=
g)
> 
> Ken goes on to say:
> 
> "Such benchmark comparisons will eventuall=
y make it possible to
> predict the performance
> of AE systems based on th=
eir location in the taxonomy. For example, one
> benchmark might be to evol=
ve a five-pointed star. This benchmark can
> be attempted
> with a system i=
n which all the dimensions of development are fixed
> except the cell
> fat=
e dimension. That dimension can vary from using only prepatterning
> to usi=
ng every
> conceivable form of fate determination, from stochastic
> self-o=
rganization to signaling,
> migration, and proliferation. The results can b=
e measured using
> several criteria: How
> fast does the objective shape ev=
olve? How often and how many genes
are reused by
> the solution genome? Is =
symmetry used, or is each point in the star
> specified by a separate
> sec=
tion of genetic code=97that is, is there emergent modularity? For
> every p=
ossible
> setting on the varying dimension (e.g., cell fate determination),=
 data
> will be available
> for comparison."
> 
> This sounds like a great =
idea. I'm wondering, though...what kind of
> response has this generated? H=
ave there been any follow up papers on
> AE systems that have tried to appl=
y such benchmarks in a systematic
> way?
> 
> Have these types of benchmark=
s been systematically applied to the 2D
> representations evolved using Hyp=
erNEAT?
> 
> I also noticed rereading Sims 1994 paper that he displays hand=
-coded
> examples of recognizable morphologies such as a primate hand, a
> =
humanoid form, and a tree structure. But I'm wondering if and/or how
> easy=
 such structures arise using his encoding when starting from a
> simple cor=
e structure and either using artificial selection or a
> fitness function t=
ailored to evoke similar structures.
> 
> --Derek
>
